Introduction to Sass

Sass is a stylesheet language that’s compiled to CSS. It allows you to use variables, nested rules, mixins, functions, and more, all with a fully CSS-compatible syntax. Sass helps keep large stylesheets well-organized and makes it easy to share design within and across projects.

Installing Sass

Inorder order to run SASS you need npm installed. You can get npm by Installing NODE JS

You can download nodejs from this link.

After installing node, open a terminal window within the project folder in any code editor of your choice.

Inorder to install sass. We have to create a Package.json file. We can create a package.json file by running the command npm init

Press enter for the all the questions and type YES

              
                Example - package.json
                  
                {
                  "name": "technical-documentation",
                  "version": "1.0.0",
                  "description": "",
                  "main": "index.js",
                  "scripts": {
                    "test": "echo \"Error: no 
                     test specified\" && exit 1"
                  },
                  "author": "",
                  "license": "ISC"
                }
                
                
                Is this OK? (yes)

If you want to learn more about package.json file. Follow this link

  • To download Sass type the below code in the terminal
npm install node-sass
  • In your package.json file, remove the code inside the script tag and add the following code. Note we have to create a directory called scss and add all the sass files there.
"sass": "node-sass -w scss/ -o dist/css/ --recursive --use-polling --polling-interval 1000"
  • Start sass using the following command -
npm run sass

Here we have created a new script called sass. So from now on after you run the script sass and save any changes to your sass file. It will automatically compile the changes to and update the css file.

Variables

Just like we have used variables in CSS. We can use variables in Sass also. Please note that the variables in Css and Sass are completely different. We use variables to store information.

  • In Order to use a variables in sass, we have prefix a $ sign. 
              
                Example - Variables
                
                $font-stack: Helvetica, sans-serif;

Just imagine you have used the colour yellow throughout the webpage without using any variable. If you want to change it, you have to go to each section and change it individually. This can become very time consuming. But on using a variable, if you change the colour assigned to the variable. It will change it throughout the page. There is more use of variable than this. We will look into it once we understand about mixins.

Partials

When your sass file is kinda long. You can separate the particular block of sass code into a separate file using a partial.

  • To create a partial, the file name has start with an _ 
              
                Example - Partials 

                _header.scss

The header.scss in the above example will contain all the style related to the header. It is completely separated from the main sass file.

  • But in order to use a partial in the main sass file, we have to use @import keyword without added .scss extension. 
              
                Example - How to import a partial

                @import 'header';
                body
                {
                  font: sans-serif;
                  background-color: #f4f4f4;
                }

Nesting

Nesting is a pretty simple. We can use sass to nest within our selector. It is one of the powerful feature of sass.

  • For example let’s imagine we have a section with a id = header. The section header has a logo with a id of nav-logo and links with a id nav-links inside it. So instead of writing CSS like this 
 
             

               Example - Normal CSS

               #header
               { 
                 background:white;
               } 
               #header
               #nav-logo
               {
                 display:block;
               } 
               #header #nav-links 
               {
                 text-decoration:none;
               }
  • We can write the scss like this as shown below. 
              

                Example - SCSS

                #header
                {
                  background:white;
                  &_#nav-logo
                  {
                    display:block;
                  }
                  &_#nav-links
                  {
                    text-decoration:none;
                  } 
                }

Here the & sign indicated the root selector. That means #header. See how easy it is. This way our code remains organized.

Mixins

Mixins are awesome. Once you get to understand it, you will never let it go. It helps to keep you code DRY. Remember the principle you started programming. It means Don’t repeat yourself.

  • You can use mixins to create a block of code (Called as functions in programming) and reuse the same block of code again anywhere in the scss file. 
             
                
                Example -  Mixin

                @mixin transform($property)
                { 
                  -webkit-transform:$property;
                  -ms-transform: $property;
                  transform: $property;
                }
  • In order to use a mixin we have to use the @include keyword. Sass variables can be passed as a parameter to a mixin.

Extend

Extend is one of the easiest functionality which can be understood by the end users of sass. It helps us in reusing the css properties and helps us in keeping our code DRY

  • We can use a % and create a placeholder selector. Sass will not compile the style which are not extended. So basically if a placeholder selector is created and is not extended then it will not reflect in the css file. 
              

                Example - 
                Creating a Placeholder Selector 1

                %card
                {
                  max-width:400px;
                  height:120px;
                  background:white;
                  padding:20px;
                  margin:10px
                }
            
          
              

                Example - 
                Creating a Placeholder Selector 2

                %error
                {
                  color:red;
                }
  • You can extend using the @extend keyword.
              

                Example - 
                Extending a Placeholder Selector

                .black-card
                {
                  @extend card;
                  background:black;
                }

In the above example sass will extend and add the card css properties to the class black-card. But it will not compile the %error placeholder to the css file. This helps us in only compiling the code needed for the project.

Operators

Mathematical operation can be done using sass. We can use all the standard math operators like +, -, *, /, and %. 

              

                Example - Operators

                .container
                {
                  width: 600px /960 *100%;
                }

That’s all about sass. It will very simple to use. Now that you have a basic idea about sass. Go and start working with it.
